label: PTX175 | Ketoconazole
tox_class: Cardiotoxicity; Genotoxicity; Nephrotoxicity; Ototoxicity; Neurotoxicity; Hepatotoxicity; Immunotoxicity
source_pka: Niu, L., et al. (2022). pH-Dependent Partitioning of Ionizable Organic Chemicals between the Silicone Polymer Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) and Water. ACS Environmental Au.
moa_drugbank: Ketoconazole interacts with 14-α-sterol demethylase, a cytochrome P-450 enzyme necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol.[A181802,T116] This results in inhibition of ergosterol synthesis and increased fungal cellular permeability due to reduced amounts of ergosterol present in the fungal cell membrane. This metabolic inhibition also results in accumulation of 14Î±-methyl-3,6-diol, a toxic metabolite. The increase in membrane fluidity is also thought to produce impairment of membrane-bound enzyme systems as components become less closely packed.
protein_binding: Ketoconazole is approximately 84% bound to plasma albumin with another 15% associated with blood cells for a total of 99% binding within the plasma.[A181802]
moa_t3db: Ketoconazole interacts with 14-Î± demethylase, a cytochrome P-450 enzyme necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in inhibition of ergosterol synthesis and increased fungal cellular permeability. Other mechanisms may involve the inhibition of endogenous respiration, interaction with membrane phospholipids, inhibition of yeast transformation to mycelial forms, inhibition of purine uptake, and impairment of triglyceride and/or phospholipid biosynthesis. Ketoconazole can also inhibit the synthesis of thromboxane and sterols such as aldosterone, cortisol, and testosterone. (A365)

aop.AOP_name: Antagonist binding to PPARα leading to body-weight loss
PPARα activation in utero leading to impaired fertility in males
Androgen receptor antagonism leading to adverse effects in the male foetus (mammals)
AhR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
NFE2L2/FXR activation leading to hepatic steatosis
Aryl hydrocarbon receptor activation leading to uroporphyria
Glucocorticoid Receptor activation leading to hepatic steatosis

targets: Nuclear receptor subfamily 1 group I member 2
Nuclear receptor subfamily 1 group I member 3
Potassium voltage-gated channel subfamily H member 2
